It's really important to show this detail of bending style differences, and is part of why it was included in the original show's intro. Speaking to Entertainment Weekly, the Avatar showrunner revealed his origins with Nickelodeon's beloved animated series, having watched Avatar with his daughter and, like many people, found its storytelling "just so epic and much beyond the audience it was targeted for." However, after joining the show, Kim had to deal with the public fallout of Avatar co-creators Michael Dante DiMartino and Bryan Konietzko leaving the project and the expectations of making the first live-action Avatar adaptation since M. Night Shyamalan's much-maligned The Last Airbender film. On trying to live up to these expectations, Kim admitted, "You'd have to be an idiot not to be intimidated a little bit. My first reaction after 'Hell yeah!' was 'Holy s---! Do I really want to do this? Is there a way to improve upon the original?' Whenever you tackle something that's already beloved by millions of fans, you have to ask yourself those questions."Ultimately, Kim decided to stick with Avatar given the original series' groundbreaking cultural roots in Eastern philosophy, mythology, and martial arts. Translating this to live-action, he pointed out, "meant setting new benchmarks for representation by featuring an all Asian and Indigenous cast," with Avatar casting Gordon Cormier, Kiawentiio Tarbell, and Ian Ousley as original Team Avatar leads Aang, Katara, and Sokka. Other notable additions include Paul Sun-Hyung Lee (Kim's Convenience, The Mandalorian) as Iroh, Dallas Liu (PEN15) as Prince Zuko, Amber Midthunder (Prey) as Princess Yue, and Yvonne Chapman (Kung Fu) as former Avatar Kyoshi, amongst many more. Likewise, Kim was enthusiastic about the chance to retell Avatar over a decade after it created a multimedia franchise, stating, "That was really appealing to me, being able to bring this story to a new generation."-CBR
